an4.108:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of oxen.
an4.108:4.3: ~One hostile to its own herd, not others; ~one hostile to other herds, not its own; ~one hostile to both its own herd and others; and ~one hostile to neither its own herd nor others.
an4.108:4.4: These are the four kinds of oxen.
an4.108:4.5: In the same way, these four people similar to oxen are found in the world.
an4.108:4.7: ~One hostile to their own herd, not others; ~one hostile to other herds, not their own; ~one hostile to both their own herd and others; and ~one hostile to neither their own herd nor others.
an4.108:5.1: And how is a person hostile to their own herd, not others?
an4.108:5.2: It’s when a person intimidates their own following, not others.
an4.108:5.3: That’s how a person is hostile to their own herd, not others.
an4.108:5.4: That person is like a ox that’s hostile to its own herd, not others.
an4.108:6.1: And how is a person hostile to other herds, not their own?
an4.108:6.2: It’s when a person intimidates the followings of others, not their own. …
an4.108:7.1: And how is a person hostile to both their own herd and others?
an4.108:7.2: It’s when a person intimidates their own following and the followings of others. …
an4.108:8.1: And how is a person hostile to neither their own herd nor others?
an4.108:8.2: It’s when a person doesn’t intimidate their own following or the followings of others.
